fields: Serotonin/5HT antagonists

MOA: antagonise 5HT3 receptors.

E.g.: Ondansetron, granisetron

Indications: cancer chemotherapy emesis and postoperative N&V.

ADRs: constipation, flushing, headache, fatigue .
Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)

MOA: irreversible inhibition of proton pumps (H+/K+ ATPase) of gastric parietal cells. Reducing gastric acid secretion. 

E.g.: Lansoprazole, omeprazole, pantoprazole.

Indications: Dyspepsia, peptic ulceration, GORD, prophylaxis against NSAID overuse.

ADRs: nausea, diarrhea, fatigue, flatulence, abdominal pain.
Bulk laxatives

MOA: addition of insoluble fibre to faecal matter makes it bigger and softer, will also distend GIT and activate stretch receptors (increasing parasympathetic activity).

E.g.: Isphaghula, Methylcellulose

Indications: constipation (small hard stool)

ADRs: Flatulence, abdominal distension, bloating
Osmotic laxatives

MOA: use of solute which will cause the entry of water (hypertonic) to GIT lumen by osmosis.

E.g.: Lactulose, macrogols 

Indications: constipation, hepatic encephalopathy 

ADRs: flatulence, abdominal distension, bloating, cramps, electrolyte disturbances
Stool softeners (laxative)

MOA: reduces tension between stool and gut wall by lubricating stool.

E.g.: Liquid paraffin, docusate sodium.

Indications: faecal impaction. 

ADRs: Impairment of synthesis/absorption of fat soluble vitamins (ADKE).
Stimulant (laxative)

MOA: induces peristalsis and GI secretions by stimulating enteric nervous system (submucosal/myenteric plexuses) - part of ANS.

E.g.: Senna, bisacodol

Indications: opioid induced constipation

ADRs: abdominal cramp, obstruction (impaction)
Antihistamine (antiemetic)

MOA: antagonist of H2 receptors in the gastric parietal cells. 

E.g.: Ranitidine 

Indications: Dyspepsia, peptic ulceration, GORD, vestibular pathology

ADRs: Antimuscarinic effects (dry mouth, drowsiness, blurred vision, urinary retention).
Dopamine antagonist

MOA: antagonises dopamine receptors (D2/D3 receptors) in the gastric pylorus and dudodenum to increase in gastric emptying. 
     Additional: also blocks dopamine receptors in the medulla oblongata - reducing nausea.

E.g.: Domperidone , Metoclopramide

Indications: drug induced (opioid) nausea, bloating

ADRs: dizziness, drowsiness, extrapyramidal side effects
Antimuscarinics

MOA: antagonise muscarinic (M3 ?) receptors.

E.g.: hyoscine butylbromide

Indications: Motion sickness, GI cramp

ADRs: Dry mouth, drowsiness, blurred vision, urinary retention
Levomepromazine (special antiemetic in formulary)

MOA: mixed - D2 antagonist, H1 antagonist, muscarinic receptor antagonsist, 5HT2a receptor antagonist.

Indications: Palliative care, restlessness

ADRs: raised ESR, hyperglycemia
Cytoprotective prostaglandin analogue

MOA: Analogue of PGE1, reduces H+ secretion and stimulates bicarbonate and mucus secretion. 

E.g.: Misoprostol

Indication: Prophylaxis against NSAID-induced damage

ADRs: diarrhoea, abdominal pain, N&V, flatulence, dyspepsia
Antispasmotic

MOA: phosphodiesterase inhibtor (?MOA in formulary). Has anticholinergic (antagonise nAChr - like curare) effects.

E.g.: Mebeverine

Indication: IBS

ADRs: Indigestion, constipation, dizziness, loss of appetite, bradycardia
Antidiarrhoeal

MOA: opioid which reduces colonic activity by presynaptic inhibition of parasympathetic fibres (opioid receptors mediate Gi induced increase of K+, decrease of cAMP)

E.g.: Loperamide

Indication: Diarrhoea

ADRs: N&V, flatulence, headache (dehydration), drowsiness
Anti-obesity

MOA: Inhibit pancreatic lipase action.

E.g.: Orlistat

Indication: Obesity (adjunct)

ADRs: oily leakage from rectum, flatulence, faecal urgency/incontinece, liquid or oily stool
5-aminosalicylates

MOA: (anti-inflammatory) stimulate synthesis of 5-aminoslicylic acid; which inhibits leukotriene and prostanoid formation, reduces free radical scavenging and decreases neutrophil chemotaxis.

E.g.: Mesalazine, sulfasalazine 

Indication: IBD (Crohn's and UC), Rheumatoid arthritis

ADRs: diarrhoea, N&V, abdominal pain, hypersensitivity reactions (rash and urticaria)
Beta-2 agonists (long acting 8-12hrs)

MOA: (via sympathetic nervous system) increases cAMP through Gs; cAMP activates PKA which inhibits MLCK (therefore no Ca2+ release and subsequent bronchoconstriction). 

E.g. Salmeterol and formoterol. 

Indicated in asthma and COPD. 

ADRs: Tremors, tachycardia, hypokalaemia.
Antihistamines

MOA: Antagonise H1 receptors to dampen type 1 hypersensitivity response (IgE mediated action of mast cells and basophils). 

E.g. Chlorphenamine, cetirizine, loratidine.

Indications: poorly controlled chronic asthma.

ADRs: misregulated hypersensitivity reactions.
Corticosteroids

MOA: immunosuppresive action, particularly stimulates the production of lipocortin which inhibits phospholipase A2 (reducing release of cytokines).

E.g. Budenoside, Beclometasone, Dexamethazone

Indication: asthma (preventions), hayfever, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

ADRs: hoarse voice and oral candidiasis
Cromones

MOA: unclear. May prevent mast cell degranulation / eosinophil activation.

E.g. Sodium cromoglicate. 

Indications: Asthma (prevention), allergic rhinitis

ADR: throat irritation
Beta<sub>2</sub>-agonists (fast acting)

MOA: agonist beta2 receptors to cause bronchodilation (Gs mechanism leads to downregulation of MLCK and inhibited Ca2+ release).

E.g. Salbutamol, Terbutaline.

Indications: Asthma (acute onset), COPD.

ADRs: tremors, tachycardia, hypokalaemia
Leukotriene receptor antagonist

MOA: antagonises leukotriene receptors which inhibits bronchoconstriction and promotes bronchodilation. 

E.g. Montelukast, Zarfirlukast.

Indications: Asthma (prevention), NSAID induced bronchospasm.

ADRs: GI disturbances, headache, hypersensitivity, dry mouth.
Muscarinic receptor antagonist

MOA: (all via Vagus) antagonises ACh at M3 muscarinic receptors preventing bronchoconstriction and mucus secretion.

E.g. Ipratropium, tiotropium.

Indications: COPD. 

ADRs: dry mouth, blurry vision and urinary retention.
Xanthines

MOA: inhibits phosphodiesterase and is an adenosine receptor antagonist. 

E.g. Theophylline, Aminophylline

Indications: 2nd line for chronic asthma, COPD. 

ADRs: GI disturbances, tachycardia, anxiety, seizures.
Antihistamine

MOA: antagonise H2 histamine receptors.

E.g.: Ranitidine

Indications: dyspepsia, peptic ulcer, GORD

ADRs: sedation, antimuscarinic affects (dry mouth, drowsiness, blurred vision, urinary retention
Weak opioids

MOA: weak opioid is catalysed to morphine by liver enzyme (CYP2D6). Morphine acts at μ-opioid receptor (coupled with a Gi pathway presynaptically and Gs postsynaptically), the overall effect is to reduce action potential transmission of pain.

Presynaptic neurone: inhibition of AC and VG Ca2+ channels.

Postsynaptic neurone: K+ channels are activated (hyperpolarising), making it harder to reach the action potential threshold. 

E.g.: Codeine, dihydrocodeine, tramadol 

Indications: mild to moderate pain.

Contraindications: acute respiratory depression, paralytic ileus, raised intracreanial pressure following head trauma, comatose. 

ADRs: constipation, dry mouth, hypotension, respiratory depression (overdose)
Strong opioids

MOA: acts directly on μ-opioid receptors to stimulate Gi pathways presynaptically and Gs postsynaptically. Inhibiting AC and VG Ca2+ channels presynaptically and activating VG K+ postsynaptically. 

E.g.: Morphine, fentanyl 

Indications: moderate to severe pain

Contraindicadtions: respiratory depression

ADRs: constipation, hormone imbalance (e.g. it suppresses LH), osteoporosis, addiction
NSAIDs

MOA: can act through non-specific inhibition of COX1/COX2 receptors. These reduce the effects of prostaglandins. In COX1 pathway PGE2 is blocked leading to reduced mucus secretion. In COX2 pathways PGI2 is blocked leading to a reduction in pain, fever and inflammation.

E.g.: paracetamol, naproxin, ibuprofen, aspirin

Indications: mild pain

Contraindications: severe asthma, 

ADRs: GI bleeding, thrombosis (reduced prostacyclin, needed to inhibit platelet activation), kidney insufficiency (COX1 pathway affects renal homeostasis, GFR), bronchospasm
Opioid receptor antagonist

MOA: binds to μ-opioid receptor and competitvely inhibits the effects of opioids. 

E.g.: naloxone 

Indications: opioid overdose

Contraindications: allergy to naloxone

ADRs: sweating, severe nausea, severe headache, agitation, anxiety, confusion, tinnitus
Depolarising muscle relaxants

MOA: bind to nAChr at NMJs and agonise them. The muscle is held in a state of depolarisation because suxamethonium is longer-acting than ACh and Acetylcholinesterase will not break it down.  

E.g.: suxamethonium

Indications: general anaesthesia 

ADRs: hypotension, increased salivation, muscle pain, rash.
Non-depolarising muscle relaxants

MOA: antagonises ACh at nAChr and leads to a hyperpolarisation of the NMJ. Muscle cannot contract and is held in a state of 'relaxation'.

E.g.: curare based drugs, rocuronium 

Indications: general anaesthetic 

ADRs: sweating, rashes, flushing (vasodilation), apnoea, respiratory depression
Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor

MOA: stops the breakdown of ACh in the synaptic cleft and increases its effect. This can help overcome the effects of non-depolarising nAChr antagonists such as rocuronium (by increasing [ACh] which can competitively bind to nAChr).

E.g.: Neostigmine 

Indications: reversal of curare poisoning (possible iatrogenic)

ADRs: cholinergic - hypotension, bradycardia, vasodilation, salivation, bronchoconstriction
mAChr antagonist

MOA: antagonises ACh at muscarinic receptors. Leads to antimuscarinic effects. 

E.g.: atropine (belladonna)

Indications: reduce cholinergic ADRs

ADRs: constipation, reduced bronchial secretions, urinary retention, dry mouth, flushing.
ACE inhibitors

MOA: inhibits angiotensin converting enzyme or ACE. This prevents the conversion of Angiotensin I (inactive) to Angiotensin II (active). 

E.g.: Captopril, Enalapril, Lisinopril, Perindopril, Ramipril

Indications: Hypertension (1st line), post-MI, chronic heart failure, diabetic neuropathy

Contraindications: not recomended in gestational hypertension, not always effective in Afro-Caribbean ethnicity because they have low levels of renin endogenously. 

ADRs: hypotension, dry cough (ACE synthesised in lungs),
Beta-blockers

MOA: Full antagonists of beta-adrenoreceptors dampening the sympathetic pathway (Gs) of beta-blockers. Antagonism of beta-1 is cardio/kidney specific (inhibit renin release, and dampen cardiac accelerator nerves), whereas beta-2 acts on smooth muscle (vasocontriction - but role of alpha1 is greater), and beta-3 on adipose tissue (blocks lipolysis). 

E.g.: propanalol (non-selective), atenolol and bisoprolol (beta1 selective)

Indications: Antiarrhythmic, Hypertension, Chronic heart failure (stable), angina, post-MI

ADRs: bradycardia, dizziness, fatigue, hypotension, bronchospasm, dyspnoea
Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)

MOA: antagonise angiotensin II receptor type 1 (AT1) receptors. Blocking angiotensin II Gq mechanism.

E.g.: Candesartan, losartan, valsartan 

Indications: hypertension (if ACEi not tolerated), chronic heart failure, diabetic neruopathy 

ADRs: dizziness, headache, hyperkalaemia, orthostatic hypotension, renal impairment
Aldosterone antagonists

MOA: blocks the affect of aldosterone at the mineralocorticoid receptor (MCR). Antagonism leads to reduction of sodium reabsoption (less Na+/K+ ATPase and Na+ in the nephron/PCT).

E.g.: Spironolactone, eplerenone

Indications: hypertension, oedema (antidiuretic), congestive heart failure, ascites in liver disease

ADRs: polyuria, hyponatraemia, hyperkalaemia, mild hypotension, gynecomastia/testicular atrophy (can block androgen MRC).
alpha blockers

MOA: antagonises alpha-1 adrenergic (epinephrine/norepinephrine) receptors (Gq) and leads to vasodilation/ smooth muscle relaxation - is more important than beta-2 blockers in arterial tone. 

E.g.: doxazosin, indoramin

Indications: resistant hypertension, prostatic hypertrophy 

ADRs: hypotension, dizziness, syncope, orthostatic/postural hypertension (hypotension reducing efficacy of barorecptor response)
Anti-anginal

MOA: Inhibition of the cardiac pacemaker current (funny current), in the SAN/AVN of right atrium. 

E.g.: Ivabradine 

Indications: Angina (chronic stable), heart failuer (where LVEF>35% and HR>70bpm)

Contraindications: pts taking macrolides, antretrovirals or azole antifungals (inhibitors of CYP3A4)

ADRs: luminous phenomina (blockage of retina channels simmilar to the funny channel), bradycardia, first degree AV heart block, dizziness, ventricular ectopics
Anticoagulants (injectable)

MOA: Activates antithrombin III.

E.g.: Unfractionated heparin, dalteparin, enoxaparin 

Indications: Immediate coagulation, prophylaxis against thrombosis

ADRs: bleeding, warfarin necrosis (pts with low protein C can experierence), osteoporosis, calcification
Anticoagulants (oral)

MOA: variable. Dabigatran is a thrombin inhibitor. Warfarin is a Vit K antagonist. 

E.g.: Dabigatran and warfarin

Indications: prophylaxis against thrombosis, atrial fibrillation (thromboprophylaxis)

Contraindications: pregnancy 

ADRs: bleeding, warfarin necrosis, osteoporosis, purple toe syndrome (small cholesterol emboli lodging in the distal feet), calcification
Antiplatelet drugs

MOA: generally drugs which decrease platelet aggregation and inhibit thrombus formation in the arterial circulation. They have 4 main MOAs: inhibition of platelet COX (aspirin); 
ADP/P2Y12 receptor antagonist (clopidogrel); 
phophodiesterase inhibitor -> inhibition of adenosine reuptake (dipyridamole); 
inhibition of glycoprotein IIb/IIa receptors (Tirofiban).

E.g.: Aspirin, clopidogrel, dipyridamole, tirofiban

Indications: Thromboprophylaxis for MI/CVA, atrial fibrillation (thromboprophylaxis), post-MI, prophylaxis of MI (Tirofiban)

ADRs: perfuse bleeding from cuts, GI disturbances including pain and diarrhoea, bruising/bleeding under the skin
Bile binding agents

MOA: bind to bile in the GIT and prevents its reabsorption. It exchanges its chloride ions with the anioic bile acids to form insoluble complexes which are egested in faeces. 

E.g.: Colestyramine 

Indications: Hyperbilirubinaemia, liver disease

ADRs: constipation, increased plasma triglycerides
Calcium channel blockers (dihydropyridine)

MOA: block L-type Ca2+ channels in vascular smooth muscle. This promotes vasodilation. 

E.g.: Amlodipine, nifedipine

Indications: Hypertension (1st line), angina 

ADRs: hypotension, dizziness, polyuria, drowsiness, insomnia
Calcium channel blockers (Class IV antiarrhythmics)

MOA: inhibition of cardiac (and smooth muscle) L-type Ca2+ channels.

E.g.: Diltiazem, Verapamil

Indications: Antiarrhythmic, SVT, hypertension, angina 

ADRs: bradycardia, constipation, nausea, headache, tiredness
Cardiac glycosides

MOA: Inhibits Na+/K+ATPase in the myocardium. This increases IC sodium levels, sodium can then bind to contractile proteins and increase the strength of myocardial contraction. 

E.g.: Digoxin

Indications: Atrial fibrillation, chronic heart failure, antiarrhythmic

ADRs: fatigue, N&V, anorexia, bradycardia
Catecholamines

MOA: binds to adrenergic receptors to work through the sympathetic nervous system. Receptors include alpha-1 (Gq), alpha-2 (Gi), beta-1 (Gs) and beta-3 (Gs). 

E.g.: epinephrine, norepinephrine 

Indications: anaphylaxis, cardiopulmonary resuscitation

ADRs: N&A, dyspnoea, palpitations, sweating, dizziness, anxiety
Class I antiarrhythmics

MOA: inhibition of Na+ channels and slowing of SAN firing. 

E.g.: Lidocaine, flecanide 

Indications: VT, anti-arrhythmic, local anaesthetic 

ADRs: hypotension, bradycardia, bronchospasm, sleepiness, muscle twitching, confusion, numbness, vomitting
Class II antiarrhythmics

MOA: antagonism of adrenergic beta1-receptors. Basically beta-blockers as antiarrhythmics.

E.g.: sotalol 

Indications: paroxysmal AF, antiarrhythmic

ADRs: fatigue, dizziness, bradycardia, palpitations, shortness of breath
Class III antiarrhythmics

MOA: blocking of K+ channels in the myocardium leading to prologation of action potential (since cell cannot repolarise).

E.g.: Amiodarone, dronedarone, sotalol (also class II)

Indications: AF, arrhythmia 

ADRs: cardiac hypothyroidism (since amiodarone has Iodine, leads to bradycardia/arrhythmia), pulmonary fibrosis (increased retension of CO), gynecomastia
Fibrates

MOA: activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR), which is a class of IC receptors modulating fat/carbohydrate metabolism and adipose tissue differentiation. They increase HDL and lower triglyceride in blood. 

E.g.: Benzafibrate, fenofibrate

Indications: hypertriglycaemia, dyslipidaemia, T2DM

ADRs: gastric myopathy (creatine kinase elevation), gallstones (they increase the cholesterol content of bile), rhabdomyolysis (with statins), renal insufficiency
Fibrinolytics

MOA: enzyme which activates plasminogen (converting to plasmin), which will trigger the cascade of events involved in clot/thrombus dissolution. 

E.g.: Streptokinase

Indications: Clot busting in MI, pulmonary embolism, arterial thromboembolism 

Contraindications: second use in a persons lifetime is not recommended 

ADRs: nausea, bleeding, hypotension, allergiic reactions
Statins

MOA: HMG-CoA reductase inhibition prevents the synthesis of endogenous lipoproteins by hepatocytes. Also increases the uptake of LDL. 

E.g.: Atorvastatin, fluvastatin, pravastatin, simvastatin 

Indications: Hypercholesterolaemia, high cardiovascular risk, post-MI

Contraindications: pregnancy and breastfeeding, active liver disease

ADRs: GI effects, heopatobiliary effects, muscle pain, rashes, increased risk of T2DM, liver abnormalities.
Loop diuretics

MOA: Inhibits Na+/K+/2Cl- co-transporter in ascending loop of Henle (~25% sodium). Competes for the binding site of Cl-.

E.g.: Furosemide, bumetanide

Indications: chronic heart failure, renal failure, LV failure, ascites in the liver

Contraindications: Anuria (could lead to potential irreversible kidney failure)

ADRs: ototoxicity, hypovolaemia, hypomagnesasemia
Nitrates

MOA: provides NO to cell. In the endothelium of arteries this triggers the production of cGMP 2nd messenger -> protein kinase G which then reduces contration (stopping Ca2+). Leads to vasodilation, decreased preload (venodilation).

E.g.: Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN), isosorbide mononitrate

Indications: angina, chronic heart failure

ADRs: postural hypotension, flushing, headache
Potassium channel activators

MOA: activate ATP-sensitive K+ channels and lead to the release of NO. NO via cGMP leads to decreased Ca2+ and vasodilation. 

E.g.: Nicorandil

Indications: Angina, post-MI, atherosclerotic disease

ADRs: palpitations, weakness, vomitting, perianal ulceration
Potassium sparing diuretic (mineralocorticoid antagonist)

MOA: mineralocorticoid antagonist which competitively binds to aldosterone receptors (type 1?) and prevents the expression of genes for Na+/K+-ATPase and Na+ channels in the PCT. 

E.g.: Eplerenone, spironolactone 

Indications: Chronic heart failure, weak diuresis, ascites, oedema

ADRs: hyperkalaemia, hyponatraemia, confusion, metabolic acidosis (H+ also retainded with K+)
Potassium sparing diuretic

MOA: blocks aldosterone sensitive Na+ channels in the late DCT and collecting duct (normally reabsorbs 1-2% Na+, reduced secretion of K+.

E.g.: Amiloride 

Indications: oedema, prevention of hypokalaemia (if on other diuretics)

ADRs: hyperkalaemia, metabolic acidosis
Thiazide and thiazide-like diuretics

MOA: Inhibition of Na+/Cl- symporter in the DCT (normally 5% sodium). 

E.g.: Bendroflumethiazide, chlortalidone, indapamide

Indications: hypertension, heart failure

Contraindications: electrolyte derangement, Addison's disease, renal imparment

ADRs: hypercalcaemia, fall in TPR (due to hypercalcaemia), hyperuraemia (gout), hyperglycaemia
Penicillin

MOA: Inhibition of transpeptidase, which cross-links peptidoglycans (NAG and NAM) in the bacterial cells wall. 

E.g.: Amoxicilin, benzylpenicillin, co-amoxyclav (addition of clavulanic acid prevents breakdown of beta-lactamases), flucloxacillin, phenoxymethyl penicillin

Indications: More effective agains gram-positive bacteria (cell wall directly exposed), Chest infections, UTIs, cellulitis, pneumonia

ADRs: allergic reaction, nausea, rash, superinfection (due to resistance), diarrhoea
Glycopeptidases

MOA: Inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting growth of the peptidoglycan chain.

E.g.: Vancomycin

Indications: against gram-positive cocci, mainly bacteriostatic (except enterococci). In treatment of Clostridium difficile they can be ingested and required only to be distributed to gut (not enter blood -> peripheral tissues)

ADRs: nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity (reversible upon cessation of therapy), red man syndrome (bulk histamine release as a result of drug admin),
Aminoglycosides

MOA: Irreversibly bind to bacterial robosomes leading to an inhibition of protein synthesis.

E.g.: Gentamicin

Indications: (aerobic) gram-negative antibacterial. Septacaemia, endocarditis, acute pyelonephritis, peritonitis, billary tract infections, conjunctivitis

ADRs: excacerbates weakness in myasthenia gravis, contraindicated in patients with mitochondrial diseases as interactions can lead to irreversible hearing loss, tinnitus, cardiac toxicity and renal toxicity.
Cephalasporins

MOA: binds to beta-lactam binding sites and inhibits cell wall synthesis. 

E.g.: cefalexin, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime

Indications: gram positive bacteria (later generation are better against gram negative, at the expense of gram positive). Septicaemia, pneumonia, UTIs,Biliary tract infections, Peritonitis

ADRs: diarrhoea, nausea, rash, electrolyte disturbances
Macrolides

MOA: prevent the translocation movement (peptidyltransferase) of bacterial ribosome (50S subunit) along the mRNA - preventing protein synthesis. Their action is bacteriostatic. 

E.g.: Azithromycin, clarithromycin, erythromycin

Indications: Chlamydia, pneumonia, cellulitis, chest infections acne
Specifics: H. pylori, Campylobacter

ADRs: myopathy (CYP450 inhibition), arrhythmia (QT prolongation, torsades de pointes), nausea (from enterohepatic recycling), cholestasis (bile cannot flow into duodenum).
Tetracycline

MOA: inhibition of protein synthesis. It binds to the 30S subunit of the ribosome and prevents tRNA binding and therefore elongation of amino acid chain. 

E.g.: Tetracycline, doxycycline 

Indications: broad spectrum (initially both gram +/-). Chlamydia, chest infection, Lyme's disease, periodontal disease, MRSA, malarial prophylaxis

ADRs: vommiting, diarrhoea, rash and loss of appetite, renal problems, photosensitivity
Quinolones

MOA: Enter the bacterial cell through porins. Leads to inhibition of bacterial DNA gyrase (gram negative) and topoisomerase IV (gram positive). Possibly also inhibit synthesis of mitochondrial DNA.

E.g.: Ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin

Indications: (broad spectrum). Good against IC pathogens such as Legionella or Mycoplasma. UTIs also.

ADRs: torsades de pointes (QT elongation due to blockage of K+ VG channels), long term use can lead to tendonitis, diarrhoea, nausea, vomitting, insomnia,, restlessness, convulsions.
Sulphonamides and trimethoprim

MOA: Inhibition of folate synthesis (binds to dihydrofolate reductase) and reduction of DNA/RNA precursors.

E.g.: Tetracycline, doxycycline 

Indications: generally against aerobic bacteria. UTIs, use of both classes of drugs can increase efficacy synergistically. 

ADRs: thrombocytopenia (low folic acid leading to low platelets and potentially megablastic anaemia), hyperkalaemia (rimethoprim antagonism of Na+ channels in the DCT leads to relative reabsorption of K+), nausea, vomitting, rash, diarrhoea, photosensitivity.
Metronidazole

MOA: DNA damage due to toxic oxygen product build up. 

E.g.: Metronidazole

Indications: Protozoal infections, anaerobic infections, Rosaceae, H. pylori, peritonitis, C. difficile

ADRs: nausea, diarrhoea, weight loss, abdominal pain, dizziness
Antituberculosis

MOA: 
Ethambutol inhibits arabinosyl transferase involved in cell wall synthesis.
Isoniazid inhibits synthesis of mycolic acid.
Pyrazinamide has unclear MOA. Effective against rapidly dividing mycobacteria.
Rifampicin inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

E.g.: Ethambutol, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, rifampicin 

Indications: Tuberculosis

ADRs: thrombocytopenia (R), hepatitis (P, R, I), rash ( R, P, E)
Anti-flu

MOA: neuramidase inhibition which prevents the entry and release of the viral particles from the host cells. 

E.g.: Oseltamivir, zanamivir 

Indications: Influenza (A / B)

ADRs: bronchospasm, nausea and vomitting, hepatitis, anaphylaxis, arrhythmias
Anti-viral (herpes)

MOA: inhibition of herpes virus DNA polymerase.

E.g.: Aciclovir, Valaciclovir (prodrug of aciclovir)

Indications: Shingles, herpes-zoster virus (HZV), herpes simplex

ADRs: nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, agitation, vertigo
Linezolid

MOA: inhibits formation of 70S ribosome and initiation of protein synthesis.

Indications: gram positive bacteria with high resistance to other antibiotics. MRSA, Streptococci, vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE)

ADRs: common- headache, diarrhoea, rash and nausea. Serious: serotonin syndrome, bone marrow suppression leading to thrombocytopenia, lactic acidosis.
Mupirocin

MOA: inhibition of bacterial protein and RNA synthesis (binding to bacterial tRNA). Often applied topically by cream.

Indications: MRSA

ADRs: itchyness, rash, headache, nausea
Antifungal (triazoles)

MOA: Inhibition of P450 dependent demethylase which converts lanosterol to ergosterol; the accumulation of lanosterol disrupts fungal membrane.

E.g.: Fluconazole, itraconazole

Indications: fungal infections such as candidasis or histoplasmosis

ADRs: vomiting, diarrhoea, rash, increased transaminases (ALT/AST) indicating liver damage
Antifungals (imidazoles)

MOA: Inhibition of P450 dependent demethylase (binding of N3 to haem of P450) which converts lanosterol to ergosterol; the accumulation of lanosterol disrupts fungal membrane. 

E.g.: Clotrimazole

Indications: fungal infections. Athelete's foot, ringworm, vaginal yeast infections, oral candidiasis

ADRs: itching, nausea and vomiting. Abnormal LFTs. Vaginal burning sensation, soreness, oedema or discharge from vagina or penis (of sexual partner)
Antifungals (ergosterol acting)

MOA: binds to ergosterol and disrupts fungal membrane.

E.g.: Amphotericin, nystatin

Indications: yeast infection (A), musculocutaneous candida infections (N)

ADRs: burning, itching, rash. Nausea and vomiting when taken orally.
Griseofulvin

MOA: interferes with fungal microtubules (binds to tubulin and inhibits mitosis) and nucleic acid synthesis (binding to keratin precursors and latering gene transcription ot give them fungal resistance).

Indications: tinea infections

ADRs: allergic reactions, nausea, diarrhoea, insomnia, fatigue/lethargy.
Terbinafine

MOA: inhibits the conversion of squalene to lanosterol, with the accumulation of squalene causing cell death. 

Indications: fungal infections. Ringworms, pityriasis versicolor, fungal nail infections.

ADRs: nausea, diarrhoea, headache, cough, rash, eleveated AST/ALT - hepatitis
Antithyroid

MOA: decreases the rate of synthesis of thyroid hormone (T3 and T4) by inhibiting the action of thyroperoxidase (TPO). TPO reduces Iodide to Iodine, which is then coupled with tyrosine. 

E.g.: Carbimazole (prodrug), methimazole 

Indications: Hyperthyroidism, Graves' disease

ADRs: hypothyroidism, bone marrow suppression (due to reduced PTH and more bone being laid down - reducing marrow space), rash, puritis, disruption of HPO axis, congenital defects when prescribed during pregnancy (rare), foetal hypothyroidism.
Biguanides

MOA: unknown. Decreases hepatic gluconeogensis and increases insulin sensitivity by antagonising the action of glucagon (promotes GLUT4 phosphorylation). AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) promotes fatty acid oxidation and supresses lipid synthesis. 

E.g.: Metformin

Indications: (1st line) T2DM, prediabetes, gestational diabetes, female infertility, PCOS,

ADRs: diarrhoea, cramps, nausea and vomitting, increased flatulence, hypothyroidism (reduce TSH), malabsorption (from GI irritation), lactic acidosis (if prescribed to comorbidities such as renal insufficiency or CHF)
Corticosteroids (endocrine)

MOA: diffuses through the plamsa membrane receptor and binds to cytoplasmic receptors, then transported to nucleus where regulates gene transcription. Upregulation of lipocortin, which inhibits phospholipase A2.

E.g.: Hydrocortisone, prednisolone 

Indications: anti-inflammatory, eczema, UC, severe asthma

ADRs: increased risk of systemic infection (immunosupression), gynecomastia in males (supression of DHEA in zona reticularis), anxiety and depression (withdrawal from steroid euphoria), fluid retention and hypertension, steroid induced osteoporosis (inhibition of osteoblast, GI calcium absorbtion and urine calcium loss)
Gliptins

MOA: prevents the action of DPP-4 (cleaves and inactivates GLP-1 incretin). This leads to increased levels of GLP-1 and can act to suppress the secretion of glucagon. They are at a low risk of inducing a hypo becuase they act within the body's negative feedback system. 

E.g.: Sitagliptin, vildagliptin 

Indications: T2DM

ADRs: headache, nausea, hypersensitivity and skin reaction (exogenous enzyme), heart failure (fluid retention?)
Exogenous Insulin

MOA: promote insertion of GLUT4 transporters in the plasma membrane to move glucose from the blood into the cell by facilitated diffusion. 

E.g.: actrapad (short), insulatard (medium), ultralente (long)

Indications: T1DM

ADRs: hypersensitivity reactions, hypoglycaemic attacks (from over administration), may lead to poor eating habits (running glucose high)
Exogenous thyroxine

MOA: replaces thyroxine (T4) and is cleaved to T3 which binds to nuclear receptors and upregulates BMR by increasing (Na+/K+-ATPase, and [mitochondria])

E.g.: Levothyroxine 

Indications: Hypothyroidism, Hashimoto's thyroiditis 

ADRs: mimic hyperthyroidism (narrow therapeutic window), muscle aches, osteoporosis, palpitations, insomnia, rapid weight loss, confusion, agitation
Incretins / GLP-1 analog

MOA: Activation of GLP-1 receptor to increase insulin secretion and reduce glucagon release. Also resists inactivation by DPP-4 This is linked to oral ingestion rather than IV as incretins prime the GIT for postprandial digestion (the incretin effect).

E.g.: Exenatide, liraglutide 

Indications: T2DM

ADRs: hypoglycaemic attack, proliferative effects on pancreatic cells may be associated with pancreatitis or pacreatic cancer (not proven)
Sulphonylureas

MOA: inhibit ATP sensitive K+ channels on the beta cells of the pancreas. This means that the cells are more likely to depolarise and therefore release insulin. It is a form of increasing insulin sensitivity. 

E.g.: Glibenclamide, gliclazide, tolbutamide

Indications: T2DM

ADRs: weight gain (increased action of insulin), hypo attacks, hypersensitivity, headache
Thiazolidinediones

MOA: colloquially known as glitazones. Insulin sensitisers which act by enhancing glucose oxidation in the tissues, this reduces insulin resistance. They alter gene transcription by activating gamma nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARγ).

E.g.: Pioglitazone

Indications: T2DM

ADRs: oedema, weight gain, hypo attacks, hepatitis / liver failure (strain on liver to catabolise high concentrations of drug),

note_models.name: Basic
